sites.name: Gramercy Park Dunleith Mound Group
sites.description: The park, situated on a high bluff overlooking the Mississippi River valley, includes 20 mounds still standing of an original group of 26 Middle Woodland conical mounds.

sites.name: Elizabeth Lake Nature Preserve Varga Archaeological Site
sites.description: 345-acre preserve includes an archaeological site complex.

sites.name: Powers-Walker House at Glacial Park
sites.description:
Archaeological investigations at the 
1854 Greek Revival farmhouse are 
featured in displays and at public programs.

sites.name: Elgin Area Historical  Society & Museum
sites.description:
Museum exhibits include the E. Maude and Carl Parlasca Native American Collection, housed in Old Main, an 1856 building that was once 
part of the Elgin Academy.

sites.name: St. Charles History Museum
sites.description:
The museum has over 25 exhibits on local 
history, including American Indian stone 
artifacts and handicrafts.

sites.name: Garfield Farm Inn & Museum
sites.description: Museum includes original 1840s buildings and period events and educational programs; selected artifacts from on-site excavations are displayed.

sites.name: Schingoethe Center for Native
sites.description:
The museum, relocating to the new Aurora University Welcome Center, reopens in January 
2015 including a display of ancient Native 
American artifacts.

sites.name: Addison Historical Museum
sites.description: Located in the 1892 Balzer House, this local historical museum includes an exhibit with area American Indian artifacts.

sites.name: Winfield Mounds Forest Preserve
sites.address: Winfield Road, between Geneva Road and High  Lake Road
sites.description:
The three conical mounds within the forest preserve 
are thought to date to the Late Woodland period, 
between AD 600-1000.

sites.name: Warrenville Historical  Museum
sites.description: Permanent exhibits include a display of Native American artifacts collected by an area family.

sites.name: Mitchell Museum of the  American Indian (Gichigamiin Indigenous Nations Museum)
sites.hours: Monday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM  Tuesday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM  Wednesday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM  Thursday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM  Friday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM  Saturday: 10:00 AM – 3:00 PM  Sunday: Closed  Holiday Closures: New Years Eve and Day: Easter Sunday; Memorial Day; Independence Day; Labor Day; Thanksgiving Day; Christmas Eve and Day
sites.description:
The museum, with a focus on North Ameri
can Indian art, culture, and history, includes 
some prehistoric artifacts.

sites.name: Forest Home Cemetery
sites.description:
The Forest Home Cemetery, once the 
location of a Potawatomi village and burial 
ground, has an historical monument noting 
its location.

sites.name: Chicago Portage National Historic Site
sites.description:
The first Europeans to traverse the portage 
between the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River 
system in 1673 were Marquette and Jolliet.

sites.name: Field Museum
sites.description:
The outstanding natural history and 
ethnographic exhibits at the Field Museum include 
material from Illinois archaeological sites.

sites.name: Plainfield Historical Society Museum
sites.hours: Tuesday – Thursday: 9:00 am – 12:00 pm, Saturday: 1:00 – 4:00 pm, Other times by appointment
sites.description:
Located in an old grain elevator office on Ill. 
Rte. 126, the museum has a display of local 
Native American artifacts.

sites.name: Isle a la Cache Museum
sites.description: Located on a 107-acre island in the Des Plaines River, museum exhibits recreate the fur trade era of the 18th century, when French traders encountered the native Potawatomi. The site features a replica Native American longhouse.

sites.name: Joliet Iron Works Historic Site
sites.address: Columbia Street, just east of Rte. 53 (Scott St.) and east of the Ruby St. Bridge
sites.description: Archaeological investigations at this important industrial site showed that the foundations of 19th-century blast furnaces and related facilities are still present and can be viewed along a 0.59-mile interpretive walking trail.

sites.name: Oakwood Mound
sites.description: This low, broad burial mound is located in Oakwood Cemetery, Joliet, opposite the intersection of Walnut Street and U.S. 30. The 1,000 year-old Woodland period Indian burial mound may be a little older than the Briscoe Mounds. Excavations conducted by the University of Chicago in 1928 yielded, in addition to weapons, ornaments, and implements, the scattered skeletal remains of over 300 persons.
sites.notes: Located in Oakwood Cemetery (opposite Walnut St. & U.S. 30).

sites.name: Higginbotham Woods Earthwork
sites.address: From U.S. 30 west of the I-80 interchange, go north on Gougar Rd. Half of a mound can be seen approximately 175 yards north of the Rock Island Railroad tracks and 20 yards west of Gougar Rd.
sites.description: The remaining mound, now in a City of Joliet park, was part of a Potawatomi village and burial ground located on the south side of Hickory Creek.

sites.name: Briscoe Mounds
sites.description: Situated along the northern side of the Des Plaines River valley, this mound and village site is affiliated with the Langford tradition of the Upper Mississippian, dating to around AD 1200-1500. The mounds are the largest Native American burial mounds in northern Illinois.
sites.notes: Directions: I-55 Bluff Road Exit, then south via the frontage road toward Channahon, IL.

sites.name: Putnam County Historical Society Museum
sites.hours: Pulsifer House: We & Fr 10AM-3PM; Agriculture & Historical Museum: 1st Saturday each month 9AM-1PM
sites.description: Museum with a focus on county history and agricultural heritage has a display of locally collected Native American artifacts.

sites.name: LaSalle County Historical Society Museum
sites.description: The LaSalle County Historical Society has six facilities in total, but three in one place: the Canal Warehouse Museum, the Heritage Center, and the Aitken One-Room School House. The Warehouse Museum is housed in a former limestone warehouse erected in 1848 for the Illinois & Michigan Canal. It includes extensive displays of Native American artifacts, including those excavated from the Grand Village of the Kaskaskia located across the Illinois River from Starved Rock. Other exhibits focus on the 19th Century, coal mining in Illinois, the early 20th Century, and the Civil War.

sites.name: Starved Rock State Park
sites.hours: Trails: Daily 7AM-Sunset; Visitors’ Center: Daily 9AM-4PM (except federal holidays Nov-Mar, and Juneteenth)
sites.description: Starved Rock State Park stretches for miles along the south bank of the Illinois River, beginning at Route 178 and extending east to Illinois Canyon. Archaeological research demonstrated the region has been continuously occupied since it was settled by Native Americans early in the Paleoindian period. Exhibits at the Visitors’ Center have displays on every period, from prehistory to the present.

sites.name: Grundy County Historical Society
sites.description: The museum documents the prehistory and history of the county. Exhibits include locally collected artifacts.

sites.name: Illinois and Michigan Canal National Heritage Area (Canal Corridor Association)
sites.address: I&M Canal Visitors’ Center, Gift Shop and Cafe: 754 First Street
sites.description: The Illinois and Michigan Canal, completed in 1848, extended 97 miles from Chicago to Peru-LaSalle. The Heritage Area united sixty communities in a network dedicated to preserving the memory of how important the canal was to the development of Illinois and the United States. Many member organizations have exhibits that document both the prehistory and history of this part of the Illinois Valley and neighboring regions affected by it.

sites.name: Midewin National Tallgrass Prairie
sites.address: Visitors’ Welcome Center: 30239 S. State Rte. 53
sites.hours: Trails: Daily 4AM-10PM; Welcome Center: Nov-Mar Mo-Fr 8AM-4:30PM; May-Oct Mo-Sa 8AM-4:30PM
sites.description: Nearly 20,000 acres of former farmland, once the location of the Joliet Arsenal, are undergoing restoration by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service; visitors can learn about prairie ecology and early inhabitants at the Welcome Center.

sites.name: Kankakee River State Park
sites.hours: Check the website for current list of dates and hours the park is closed.
sites.description: The park extends for 11 miles along both sides of the Kankakee River northwest of Kankakee and includes several documented archaeological sites.

sites.name: Kankakee County Historical Museum
sites.description: Permanent exhibits include American Indian artifacts related to cultural periods, with an extensive display of Potawatomi material from a nearby site.

sites.name: Camp Douglas
sites.address: South Martin Luther King Drive and E. 33rd St.
sites.description: Centered between 31st and 33rd Streets and between Cottage Grove and King Drive, there is little visible evidence of Camp Douglas today. During the Civil War it was the largest U.S. military facility in Illinois, serving as a training camp for Union soldiers, a Confederate prisoner of war camp, and a demobilization camp after the war. Archaeological projects confirmed the location and outlines of the camp.

sites.name: Stephen A. Douglas Tomb
sites.description: During his lifetime Senator Stephen A. Douglas was known as a strong promoter of Illinois and Abraham Lincoln’s political rival. He is buried in a mausoleum topped with a 46-foot-high column and statue.

sites.name: Oak Woods Cemetery
sites.description: Oak Woods Cemetery contains graves of historically significant individuals. Of special note is a mass grave of Confederate prisoners of war believed to hold more than 4,000 burials.

sites.name: Essley-Noble Museum
sites.description: Apr-Oct: We, Sa, Su 1-5PM Nov-Mar: Sa 124PM The museum, managed by the Mercer County Historical displays of artifacts donated by local collectors. Society, has an exhibit of prehistoric Native American artifacts found in Mercer County.
